ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Growth mechanism studies of ZnO nanowire arrays via hydrothermal method

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Université Paris-Est, Laboratoire Physique des Matériaux Divisés et des Interfaces (LPMDI-EA 7264)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Well-controlled ZnO nanowire arrays have been synthesized using the hydrothermal method, a low temperature and low cost synthesis method. The process consists of two steps: the ZnO buffer layer deposition on the substrate by spin-coating and the growth of the ZnO nanowire array on the seed layer. We demonstrated that the microstructure and the morphology of the ZnO nanowire arrays can be significantly influenced by the main parameters of the hydrothermal method, such as pH value of the aqueous solution, growth time, and solution temperature during the ZnO nanowire growth. Scanning electron microscopy observations showed that the well oriented and homogeneous ZnO nanowire arrays can be obtained with the optimized synthesis parameters. Both x-ray diffraction spectra and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) observations revealed a preferred orientation of ZnO nanowires toward the c-axis of the hexagonal Wurtzite structure, and HRTEM images also showed an excellent monocrystallinity of the as-grown ZnO nanowires. For a deposition temperature of 90 °C, two growth stages have been identified during the growth process with the rates of 10 and 3 nm/min, respectively, at the beginning and the end of the nanowire growth. The ZnO nanowires obtained with the optimized growth parameters owning a high aspect ratio about 20. We noticed that the starting temperature of seed layer can seriously influence the nanowire growth morphology; two possible growth mechanisms have been proposed for the seed layer dipped in the solution at room temperature and at a high temperature, respectively.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Over the last decade, ZnO nanowires have stimulated a lot of research interest due to their diverse and unique semiconductive, optic, and piezoelectric properties and their large applications such as nanogenerator of electricity [1, 2], chemical sensors [3–8], photovoltaic cells [9–11], etc. Most of these applications are dominated by surface reaction process, therefore, the exploration of novel microdevices based on the high aspect ratio ZnO nanowires are of particular interest due to their large ratio of the surface/volume compare with the bulk or thin film materials. Because the properties of ZnO nanowires strongly depend on their dimensions and morphologies, the obtaining of a well-controlled, high aspect ratio and good quality nanowire array is very important for above applications.

Many synthesis methods, such as physical or chemical vapour deposition (PVD- CVD) [12–18], pulsed laser deposition [19–21] have been widely used to obtain the high quality ZnO nanowires. However, these techniques often involve the complex procedures with sophisticated and expensive equipments. Solution-phase synthesis, such as electrochemical deposition [22–24], sol-gel [25–27], and hydrothermal methods [4, 28–31], appeared to be alternative ways to produce the large areas and well-ordered ZnO nanowires. The low investment of those methods generally operating at low temperature (below 100 °C) made them suitable for scaling up at industrial fabrication. Unlike the high temperature, the low temperature methods generally required a two-step process in order to obtain the well-organized and well-oriented nanowires on the substrate surface. The first step consisting in the deposition of a buffer layer is necessary for the homogeneous seed distribution on the substrate and, at the same time, to induce an oriented ZnO nanowire growth for the second step.

As all chemical reactions, the hydrothermal process is ruled by the chemistry laws and many factors can promote or hinder the ZnO nanowire growth. In this work, we focused on a systematic study of the synthesis parameter effects on the morphological and optical properties of the ZnO nanowires, such as the growth solution pH value, the growth temperature and growth time. For the first time, we demonstrated that the starting temperature of seed layer can also influence the nanowire growth morphology. The well-aligned ZnO nanowires have been obtained on silicon substrates with controlled parameters.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: The silicon wafers with a surface of 1.5×1.5 cm2 were used as substrate in our experiments. A rigorous substrate preparation was necessary in order to obtain a reproducible seed layer deposition quality. The silicon wafers were firstly cleaned with ultra-pure distilled water from Milli-Q system (>18 MΩ⋅cm) in an ultrasonic bath and then dried with a blow-dryer before being placed in a plasma cleaner for 5 min.

For the buffer solution preparation, the zinc acetate dihydrate (ZnAc2⋅2H2O, 0.01 M) was dissolved in the absolute ethanol (99.9 %, VWR). Then 200 μL of the buffer solution were dropped onto the silicon substrates for spin-coating and the coated substrates were annealed in a conventional laboratory oven for 15 min at 350 °C. This process leads to the formation of the nanosize ZnO seeds. In fact, the hydroxocomplexes Zn(OH) x can be obtained by the reaction between the zinc acetate dehydrate and the ethanol; and then, during the annealing, ZnO nanocrystal seeds were formed through a dehydration reaction thanks to high reaction temperature and low concentration of ZnAc2 [32]. The spin-coated buffer solution form a thin film and the annealing process forms a homogenous seed layer composed of small grains (size ∼20 nm) [33].

For the ZnO nanowire growth, the hydrothermal solution was prepared by mixing equimolar aqueous solutions (0.025 M) of the zinc nitrate (Zn(NO3)2) and the methenamine (HMTA). The pH value of the growth solution was adjusted by adding HCl or NaOH solution in order to reach the planned pH value. The substrate coated with the buffer layer was then immersed in the prepared solution by two distinguished ways: the sample was dipped directly in the solution at room temperature and then heated up to growth temperature; or the sample was dipped only when the solution attends the desired growth temperature. The growth time varied from 30 minutes to 6 hours. After the growth process, the substrate covered by ZnO nanowires was withdrawn from the solution, rinsed with the distilled water, and dried immediately.

The morphology and size distribution of the ZnO nanowires were characterized using a scanning electron microscopy (FEG–SEM, NEON 40 ZEISS) operating at 10 kV accelerating voltage. For crystalline structural identification, XRD experiments were performed with a Bruker D8 Advanced diffractometer using CuKα radiation (λ=0.1540 nm) in θ–2θ Bragg-Brentano configuration. Microstructure observations were carried out using a TECNAI G2 F20 microscope operating at 200 kV accelerating voltage.

Section2.Heading: Effect of the growth method on the ZnO nanowires morphology
Section2.Para:
In literature, there are many SEM observations that reveal the different shapes on the ZnO nanowires obtained by hydrothermal method [34–36]. In order to better understand the influence of the growth method employed to synthesize the ZnO nanowires, two distinct routes were employed (see Fig. 1). In the first route (way 1), the substrate coated with the buffer layer is dipped into the growth solution only when the desired temperature is reached; whereas in the second route (way 2), the coated substrate is dipped into the growth solution at room temperature, the kettle is sealed, and placed in the heating system. SEM characterizations (Fig. 2) revealed the difference in the shape and in the distribution between the two ways followed by the ZnO nanowire synthesis.
Fig. 1
Schematic sketch of two possible routes for ZnO nanowire array synthesis
Fig. 2
SEM images of ZnO nanowires synthesized via Way 1 (a) and Way 2 (b)

The nanowires obtained by the way 1 show a narrow diameter size distribution and the diameter seems to be uniform along the nanowire (Fig. 2a). On the other hand, the nanowires synthesized via way 2 own a wider diameter size distribution; they present a slight cone-shaped form (Fig. 2b). This diameter variation can be ascribed to the rise in temperature with the seeds inside the kettle. In fact, during the temperature rise between room temperature and the minimum temperature necessary for ZnO nanowire growth (about 60 °C, see Sect. 3.3), the ZnO seeds begin firstly to coalesce leading to the formation of the larger ZnO seeds. Those larger seeds lead to obtain the bigger nanowires during the growth process. For the slight cone-shaped form, there are two influencing parameters: the temperature and the concentration of reactants. At low temperature range (60 °C to 80 °C), both lateral and axial growth are promoted; while at high temperature range (T>80 °C) the axial growth is mainly supported. On the other hand, during the temperature increases toward the desired value (90 °C, for example), the concentration of reactants evolves also: the concentration is higher at the beginning of the growth than the end of the experience. This cone-shaped form is more obvious for the larger nanowires than the small ones, may be due to a local variation of the concentration in the solution during growth. Due to the strong perturbation on the nanowire growth induced by the solution turbulence, all of our experiences have been carried out without agitation.

In order to obtain narrower and more homogeneous nanowire arrays, the following experiments were carried out via the way 1 synthesis route. In other words, the way 1 leads to synthesis the higher aspect ratio nanowire arrays.

Section2.Heading: Effect of the pH value of growth solution
Section2.Para: It is well known that the chemical reactions are ruled by the chemistry laws during the hydrothermal processes; so many factors can promote or hinder the ZnO nanowire formation. In order to better understand the role of the pH value of the growth solution, we studied its effect on the ZnO nanowire growth by varying its value. The HCl or NaOH solution was added to adjust the pH value in the range of 6.4–7.4 at room temperature. The hydrothermal growth was then performed with the fixed pH value.

Figure 3 shows the SEM images of the ZnO nanowires synthesized by hydrothermal method during 2 h at 90 °C for different pH values. We observed that the ZnO nanowires are well oriented quasi-perpendicularly to the substrate and have a quite homogeneous diameter distribution with a nanowire density of ∼1010 wires/cm2. It is worth to note that the nanowires can be obtained for all pH value in the understudied range.
Fig. 3
SEM images of ZnO nanowires synthesized at pH of 6.4 (a), 6.6 (b), 6.8 (c), 7.0 (d), 7.2 (e), and 7.4 (f), respectively. Scale bar: 500 nm

The influence of pH value on the ZnO nanowire growth in aqueous solution is not clearly reported nowadays, especially for the pH value close to 7.0. Vernardou et al. [34] reported on the influence of pH value on the ZnO nanostructure deposition at basic values. Different morphologies can be obtained: hexagonal nanorods for pH=7, double cone-shaped tip nanorods for pH=8, nanoprisms for pH=10, and nanoflowers for pH=12. For the pH value around 7.0, we suppose that the influence of pH value for acid range (pH<7.0) is essentially due to the attack on the seed layer leading an inhomogeneous surface. The SEM image on the large scale (not shown here) showed the presence of some void areas for the pH<7.0 samples. Less influence was observed for pH>7.0. The pH=7.0 is chosen for the excellent homogeneity on the quasi-whole substrate with an excellent reproducibility. This is very promising for the device applications.

On the Fig. 3, we can observe a slight variation of the nanowire density. This density depends on the ZnO seed density. Certainly a thick seed layer can lead to obtain the dense nanowires, but in our experience, we tried to deposit a well-controlled thin seed layer in order to obtain a less dense ZnO nanowires network. This is very important for the applications such as the photovoltaic cell and the gas sensor where we need a large effective surface for p-n junction and for gas flux pass. In those cases, the very high density nanowire array should be avoided.

In Fig. 3, we can also note that the termination morphology of the nanowires is quite random. We suppose that the nanowire termination form can be influenced by several parameters: quality and orientation of the ZnO seeds, local seed concentration, etc. In general, we can observe two types of the ZnO nanowire termination: pyramid composed of
$\{1\bar{1}0x\}$ type facets and flat for c-axis direction growth.

All XRD spectra of our samples in this series are similar. Figure 4 shows the diffractogram of the sample synthesized at a pH of 7.0. From the diffraction patterns, we can conclude that only ZnO with the wurtzite structure is present in our as-grown nanowires. The good resolution of the peak revealed a good crystallinity of the ZnO nanowires. All our samples show a preferred growth direction toward the c-axis, as evidenced by SEM observation. The diffraction patterns are indexed using the cell parameters, a=0.326 nm and c=0.521 nm, determined by XRD measurements on thin films in our previous work [37].
Fig. 4
XRD diffractogram of ZnO nanowires obtained at a pH of 7.0 (2 h, 90 °C)

Section2.Heading: Effect of the growth temperature
Section2.Para:
Apart from the pH value, it is well known that the temperature and the growth time are also the main parameters allowing ZnO nanowire morphology control. We firstly studied the growth temperature effect on the ZnO nanowire deposition by performing the 2 h growth at the pH value of 7.0 and fixing the temperature at 60, 70, 80, and 90 °C, respectively. The corresponding SEM images of the as-grown nanowires at each temperature are shown in Fig. 5. It can be seen that the nanowires appear to be strongly influenced by the growth temperature. Indeed, the ZnO nanowire growth is a thermo-activated process, so the temperature greatly activates the nanowires formation, and a minimum temperature ∼60 °C is necessary to obtain the ZnO nanowires under our experimental conditions.
Fig. 5
SEM images of ZnO nanowires grown at (a) 60 °C (top view), (b) 70 °C, (c) 80 °C, and (d) 90 °C, respectively. Scale bar: 300 nm

From SEM characterization, we can also observe that the average length of the nanowires increased with the growth temperature whereas the average diameter increased slighter. That means the temperature plays an important rule in the growth kinetic along the c-axis [0001], more than the other directions.

Figure 6 represents the evolution of the average length with the growth temperature for a fixed growth time (2 h). We can note that the length near-linearly increases with the temperature, and we have estimated a rate of about 28 nm/°C from 60 to 90 °C. Guo et al. [31] reported also the existence of a minimum temperature for the ZnO nanowire growth of ∼35 °C, but with a larger precursors concentration of 0.1 M.
Fig. 6
Average length of ZnO nanowires as a function of the growth temperature

Section2.Heading: Effect of the growth time on the ZnO nanowires
Section2.Para: Afterward, we investigated the effect of the growth time on the ZnO nanowire morphology under the synthesis conditions previously presented: The samples of this series have been synthesized at 90 °C with pH of 7.0 for a growth time from 30 minutes to 6 hours.

SEM images (Fig. 7) show an evident increasing average length of the ZnO nanowires with the growth time: 450 nm-length ZnO nanowires can be obtained after 30 min growth and nanowires of 1.5 μm-length for 6 hours growth. The as-grown nanowires own an excellent monocrystallinity with a quite smooth surface aspect as shown in Fig. 8, a high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) image taken on the 1 h sample. The nanowire was scraped off from the sample and deposited on the TEM grid without any special preparation process. The HRTEM image as well as the electron pattern diffraction confirmed the preferred orientation of ZnO nanowires toward the c-axis.
Fig. 7
SEM images of ZnO nanowires synthesized for growth time of 30 min (a), 1 h (b), 2 h (c), 3 h (d), 5 h (e), and 6 h (f), respectively. Scale bar: 1 μm
Fig. 8
HRTEM image of a ZnO nanowire extracted from the nanowire array synthesized at 90 °C for 1 h

The evolution of the average length has been plotted in Fig. 9, which highlights the existence of two growth stages: the first one for a growth time until 1 hour with a growth rate of about 13 nm/min and the second one, the growth time situated between 1 hour and 6 hours with a slower growth rate of about 2.5 nm/min. These results are in agreement with those reported in literature. Green et al. [28] mentioned two growth stages for the elaboration of ZnO nanowires; all experimental conditions are similar except that they have used both the methenamine and diethylamine in the growth solution. They found two growth rates of 15 nm/min and 6 nm/min, respectively. Postel et al. [38] also reported the existence of two growth stages during the synthesis with respective rates of 10.5 nm/min and 0.85 nm/min for a precursor concentration of 0.01 M.
Fig. 9
Average length of ZnO nanowires as a function of the growth time

Section1.Heading: Conclusions
Section1.Para: Well-ordered ZnO nanowire arrays have been successfully synthesized using a hydrothermal technique. The systematic study of influencing parameters such as pH value of the growth solution, growth temperature, and growth time allows us to finally obtain narrow and high aspect ratio ZnO nanowire array. We found the optimal conditions for the hydrothermal growth: pH value of about 7.0, the growth temperature of about 90 °C, and the substrate coated with the buffer layer should be dipped into the growth solution only when the desired temperature is reached in order to obtain the more homogeneous ZnO nanowire arrays with the higher aspect ratio. The kinetic studies highlighted two growth rates of about 13 and 2.5 nm/min have been determined for early growth stage and for after 1 hour growth, respectively, in agreement quite well with those reported in literature. The fact of the higher growth rate for the c-axial direction has been explained by the crystallographic consideration of the ZnO hexagonal wurtzite structure.
